conclusion: A child with a mass of 30kg is sitting on a sled with a mass of 10kg, pulled by an adult with a force of 100N at an angle of 37° above the horizontal.
The sled moves at a constant speed along the horizontal ground.
The image shows a child on a sled being pulled by an adult with a force at an angle above the horizontal.
The force applied by the adult is 100N at an angle of 37° above the horizontal.
Horizontal component of the force is 100N × cos(37°) = 100 × 0.8 = 80N.
Vertical component of the force is 100N × sin(37°) = 100 × 0.6 = 60N.
Since the sled moves at a constant speed, the net force on the sled and child is zero.
The vertical component of the force balances the weight of the sled and child.
The weight of the sled and child is given by the vertical component of the force: 60N.
The magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground is equal to the weight of the sled, which is 60N.
